questions.question_text:
A developer is building an OmniScript and needs to save data to Salesforce and to an AWS Order Management system.

Which OmniScript element could save all of this data?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The OmniScript element that can be used to save data to Salesforce and to an AWS Order Management system is the Integration Procedure Action.

The Integration Procedure Action is used to integrate with external systems and execute actions based on the responses received. It allows developers to call external systems such as Salesforce or AWS, and pass data to them as input parameters. It can also receive responses from those systems and process them accordingly.

In this case, the developer needs to save data to both Salesforce and an AWS Order Management system. The Integration Procedure Action can be configured to call both systems and pass the data to them. The action can then wait for the responses from the systems and process them accordingly.

Therefore, the correct answer is B. Integration Procedure Action.

questions.question_text: An OmniScript updates data from one Salesforce record, but when it completes, only some of the data is updated in Salesforce. A DataRaptor Load saves the data. What error could cause this behavior? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
Correct Answer is A&B

Selected Answer: BD
The two errors that could cause this behavior are:
B. The Input JSON paths in the DataRaptor Load do not match the JSON sent from the OmniScript.
If the Input JSON paths in the DataRaptor Load do not match the JSON sent from the OmniScript, then the data sent from the OmniScript will not be mapped to the correct fields in Salesforce. This could result in only some of the data being updated.
D. The fields that are not updated are read only in Salesforce.
If the fields that are not updated in Salesforce are read-only fields, then the data sent from the OmniScript will not be updated in those fields. This could result in only some of the data being updated.
Therefore, the correct answers are B and D.
Option A is not correct as misspelling ContextID would result in an error and the DataRaptor Load would not execute at all.

choices.B: The Input JSON paths in the DataRaptor Load do not match the JSON sent from the OmniScript.
choices.D: The fields that are not updated are read only in Salesforce.
choices.C: In the DataRaptor Load, in the preview tab, the RecordId is from the wrong record type.
choices.A: ContextID is misspelled in the merge code that passes the RecordId to the DataRaptor.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Because action is inside BlockA:BlockB:Action1

Selected Answer: A
Maybe answer is A.
Because, Connect with ":".

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit below. In this Integration Procedure structure, what Send JSON Path would be used to send the output of the Action1 element to a Remote Action?

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A and C could cause missing data in an OmniScript displaying data from an API using an Integration Procedure.
Option A refers to the possibility that the Integration Procedure Action Response JSON Path could be configured to trim the missing data. This means that the JSON path configured to display the data may not include the missing data.
Option C suggests that the element name for the missing data does not match the JSON node key in the Integration Procedure Response. This means that the Integration Procedure is not able to properly map the missing data to the correct element in the OmniScript.
Options B and D are not likely to cause missing data in the Integration Procedure. Option B is related to the JSON sent from the Integration Procedure Action, which should not cause data to be missing. Option D refers to the Integration Procedure Preview Input Parameters not matching the JSON sent from the OmniScript, but this would more likely cause an error or incorrect data rather than missing data.

choices.A: The missing data is trimmed in the Integration Procedure Action Response JSON Path.
choices.D: The Integration Procedure Preview Input Parameters do not match the JSON sent from the OmniScript.
choices.B: The JSON sent from the Integration Procedure Action does not match any of the Original Input for the Integration Procedure.
choices.C: The element name for the missing data does not match the JSON node key in the Integration Procedure Response.

questions.question_text:
An OmniScript displays data from an API using an Integration Procedure, but some of the data is missing.

Which two configuration errors could cause this? (Choose two.)
A developer needs to build a DataRaptor Transform to send current weather to both an OmniScript and Card Layout. Which of these samples would be valid for the Expected Output JSON?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Option B would be the valid Expected Output JSON for this scenario as it provides the weather data in a structured format within the "Current" object, including the temperature in Fahrenheit and Celsius, and the city and state information. This structure allows for easy parsing and retrieval of the necessary data by the OmniScript and Card Layout.

Option A is not valid because it includes redundant keys and lacks a structured object.

Option C is also not valid because it includes duplicate keys for temperature values and lacks a structured object.

Option D is not valid because it is in XML format and not JSON format.
